IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
No. 6617 MEMORANDUM BRIEF
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF JUNICHI YAMAMOTO, FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
The petitioner, Junichi Yamamoto, is a citizen of the Empire of Japan and has been a resident of King County, Washington since September 17, 1917. On the 10th day of January, 1922 he was arrested by the respondant, United States Commissioner of Immigration,at Seattle, Washington, on a tele- graphic warrant sent from the Department of Labor at Washington. In the warrant of arrest he is charged with the violation of Rule 11 of the Immigration Rules and that at the time of entry he was likely to become a public charge. He was given a hearing before one Arthur J. Kahl, an Immigrant Inspector at Seattle, Washing- ton, and a complete copy of all of the testimony taken at his hearing is attached to the petition and marked Exhibit A. From the record it is apparent that the Government made no effor to prove that at the time of hearing, or any time prior thereto, the alien was likely to become a public charge. There is an entire want of evidence to indicate that such is the fact. The Government attempted to produce no evidence to show that the petitioner was at any time likely to become a public charge, but the evidence affirmatively shows that at the time of the hearing the petitioner owned a Ford truck, upon which he had paid a sum in excess of $800.00, and that he had loans outstanding in the sum of $500.00 and $120.00. In his petition he alleges that at the time he arrived in the United States he had in his possession
the sum of 800 gold yen and that since his arrival he has sub stantially paid for a Ford truck and has sent to his home in Japan the sum of $1500.00. He is a young man, thirty-one years of age, healthy and able-bodied in every way, and there is no excuse or justification in the record for holding that at any time he was likely to become a public charge.
The real reason he has been arrested and has been ordered deported is that it appears from the record that he was born in Japan; that he came directly from Japan to the United States; that he landed at Seattle, Washington; that he reached Seattle as an able-bodied seaman on the Steamship "Taiyo Maru" on September 17, 1917; that he deserted as a seaman at Seattle, Washington and has ever since been in the state; that he had no passport from Japan; that he never tried to get a passport in Japan and he didn't need one, because he was a part of the crew and a seaman on board the "Taiyo Maru"' that at the time he left the vessel in September, 1917 he did not see an Immigration official.
Since there is a total want of any evidence to indicate that the petitioner is likely to become a public charge, it remains for us to determine whether he has obtained entry into the United States in violation of Rule 11 of the Immigration Rules.
JAPANESE LABOR.
The Supreme Court of the United States makes a clean and well-defined distinction between a laborer seeking ad mission to this country and an able-bodied seaman who comes to this country on board a vessel engaged in foreign commerce. It is not proper to call the petitioner a Japanese laborer within the meaning of the Immigration rules. Our position is well sup-
-2-
ported by the case of Scharranberg vs. Dollar Steamship Company 245 U.S. 122, 62 L. ed. 189, where that court states that a seaman is never called a laborer within the terms of the various statutes concerning immigration.
But even should this court assume for the purposes of this case that the petitioner was a Japanese laborer within the meaning of the Immigration rules, still we confidently assert that there is no statute of the United States by which the pe titioner is among the excluded classes. It is a well known fact that the United States Government has steadfastly declined to enact any legislation which expressly is directed toward the exclusion of Japanese labor. The laborers from Japan are treated exactly in the same manner as is all alien labor, and in order to avoid any appearance of discrimination against the citizens of Japan the Government has declined to enact special legislation affecting Japan.
However, it appears that there was a Gentleman's Agreement between the Japanese Government and the American Govern- ment, whereby the Japanese Government denied passports to Japanese laboreres, and absolutely the only reason that Japanese labor has not come to this country is because of the refusal of the Japanese Government to permit the same. In the absence of the Gentlemen's Agreement there is nothing in our laws by which they could be excluded.
The Japanese Government, however, permits its labor- ers to come to Canada and to Mexico, and for that purpose grants to them limited passports good only for that country. It appears that these laborers holding limited passports were gaining surreptitious entry into the United States by coming to Mexico and Canada, and in order to protect the United States from the
-3-
entry of these laborers from adjoining countries, it was pro- vided in the Immigration Act of February 20, 1907, and re-enacted as the sixth proviso of Section 3 of the Immigration Act of February 5, 1917, as follows:
"That whenever the President shall be satisfied that passports issued by any foreign government to its citizens or subjects to go to any country other than the United States, or to any insular possession of the United States or to the Canal Zone, are being used for the purpose of enabling the holder to come to the continental territory of the United States to the detriment of labor conditions therein, the President shall refuse to permit such citizens or subjects of the country issuing such passports to enter the continental territory of the United States from such other country or from such insular pos- session or from the Canal Zone."
The foregoing proviso is substantially the same in both the Immigration Act of 1907 and in the Immigration Act of 1917.
It will be noticed that this proviso does not grant to the President the right to exclude all Japanese labor, but the privilege is granted to the President only to exclude such Japanese labor or such alien labor who obtain passports from their own country to countries other than the United States and which only applies implies to them when such citizens or subjects attempt to enter the United States, from or such other country to which the limited passport is directed.
Pursuant to the authority granted in the Act of February 20,1907, the President of the United States issued a proclamation which referred expressly to the citizens of Japan. This proclamation, dated March 14, 1907, after certain recitals, provided that such citizens of Japan who have received passports to go to Mexico, Canada or Hawaii, and come therefrom, be re- fused to enter the continental territory of the United States.
The Japanese Government made objections to the language contained in the foregoing proclamation and therefore
-4-
President Taft issued a new proclamation under date of February 24, 1913, which is set forth in full under Rule 11 of the Department of Labor. That proclamation reads as follows:
"Whereas, by the act entitled 'An act to regulate the immigration of aliens into the United States' approved February 20, 1907, whenever the President is satisfied that passports issued by any foreign government to its citizens to go to any country other than the United States or to any insular possession of the United States or to the Canal Zone, are being used for the purpose of enabling the holders to come to the continental territory of the United States from such country or from such insular pos- session of from the Canal Zone;
"And whereas, upon sufficient evidence produced before me by the Department of Commerce and Labor, I am satisfied that passports issued by certain foreign governments to their citizens or subjects who are laborers, skilled or unskilled, to proceed to countries or places other than the continental terri- tory of the United States are being used for the pur- pose of enabling the holders thereof to come to the continental territory of the United States to the detriment of labor conditions therein'
"I hereby order that such alien laborers, skilled or unskilled, be refused permission to enter the con- tinental territory of the United States.
"It is further ordered that the Secretary of Commerce and Labor be, and he hereby is, directed to take, through the Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization, such measures and to make and enforce such rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry this order into effect."
It cannot be too strongly emphasized that the proclamation of the President was not issued for the purpose of excluding all Japanese labor, but was issued for the sole pur- pose of excluding that Japanese labor which obtains limited pass- ports to other countries and abuses the use of such passports by obtaining entry into the United States from such countries to which they have been permitted to go by the Japanese Government.
-5-
In subdivision 3 of Rule 11 the Secretary of Labor has provided:
"If such a laborer applies for admission and presents no passport, it shall be presumed (1) that when he departed from his own country he did not possess a passport entitling him to come to the continental territory of the United States, and (2) that at the time he did possess a pass- port limited to some country or place other than the continental United States."
Of course, this rule was not intended to be ir- rebuttable presumption, and the rule clearly indicates that the President's proclamation was not enacted to exclude all Japanese labor, but was simply enacted to cover a speical field where special abuses had arisen. There can be no room for the opera- tion of the presumption found in subdivision 3 in this case. because the record conclusively shows that the petitioner had no passport from the Japanese government of any kind, and did not need one. He was designated as a part of the crew of the Japan- ese vessel and came to this country as an able-bodied seaman. His name was on the crew list which was vised by the American Consul in Japan. The petitioner came direct from Japan to the United States on board the vessel, and therefore does not in any manner come within the provisions of the President's proclama- tion or the ruels issued thereunder. The Immigrant Inspector brought out himself the fact that the petitioner had no pass- port of any kind, and it was furthermore shown that he did not need one.
We therefore assert confidently that the petitioner is not present in the United States in violation of the Presi- dent's proclamation or of the rules of the Department issued thereunder. If he had presented himself to the Immigration authorities at Seattle, Washington on September 17, 1917 it
-6-
would have been their duty to admit him.
In United States vs. Hemet, 156 Fed. 285, the United States District Court for Oregon, Wolverton, District Judge, had for consideration the question of whether two Japanese who arrived at Portland, Oregon as seamen on board the French Barque "St. Louis", and who escaped from said vessel, were unlawfully in the United States in violation of the Presi- dent's proclamation. Judge Wolverton said that the President's proclamation extended to and comprised such citizens of any foreign government as shall have passports therefrom to any country other than the United States and had used such passports for the prupose of enabling the holders to come into the United States; that neither the proviso in the Immigration law nor the President's proclamation extended to all citizen of the govern- ment issuing such passports, but only such citizens to whom limited passports has been issued. The court held that the rules of the Commissioner General went beyond the authority granted in the Act; the the Commissioner had no authority to provide that if a Japanese presents no passport the presumption shall be that he possesses one of a limited character. The court said that the Commissioner General might as well provide that if a Japanese alien presents no passport is shall be presumed that he is an idiot or a professional beggar. The court held that the two Japanese seamen did not obtain entry into this country in vio- lation of the President's proclamation.
OBTAINING ENTRY WITHOUT INSPECTION.
We believe that we have demonstrated that the government is proceeding without warrant of law in attempting to exclude the petitioner on the ground that he had obtained entry
-7-
into this country in violation of the President's proclamation. The very worse that can be said against the petitioner is that he violated the Immigration Law in failing at the time that he left his vessel to present himself to the Immigration authorities for inspection. Under Rule 22 of the Immigration Rules, adopted May 1,1917, the various grounds upon which aliens can be de- ported are classified, and the limitation in years within which deportation may be had is expressly provided for each classifi- cation. Under subdivision 1 (h) it is provided that any alien who shall have entered without inspection may be deported within three years after he obtains entry.
In Section 34 of the Immigration Act of February 5, 1917, it is provided as follows:
"That any alien seaman who shall land in a port of the United States contrary to the provisions of this act shall be deemed to be unlawfully in the United States, and shall, at any time within three years thereafter, upon the warrant of the Secretary of Labor, be taken into custody and brought before a board of special inquiry for examination as to his qualifications for ad- mission to the United States, and if not ad- mitted said alien seaman shall be deported at the expense of the appropriation for this act as provided in section twenty of this act."
It is provided in Section 36 of the same law that the owner or master of a vessel shall provide the Immigration authorities with lists of all the seamen on board the vessel. Rule 10 of the Immigration Rules of May 1, 1917, makes elaborate provisions for the landing of alien seamen. In subdivision 1 of Rule 10 seamen are defined, in subdivision 2 provision is made for the collection of a head tax upon those who are discharged in a port of the United States. In subdivision 3 it is prov- ided for the issuance to the seamen of an identification card containing his photograph. It is provided that no seaman shall
-8-
